oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civilian Conservation Corps Camp-TVA-45-Company 444
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic group photograph labeled Civilian Conservation Corps Camp-TVA-45-Company-494 Norris, Tenn. Officers listed: P. R. Chaplin, D. R. Griner, W. D. May, W. C. Cobb, W. T. Davis. The uniformed men are standing outdoors in front of long barracks.

The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was created in 1933 and was one of the first New Deal projects. It was designed to ease the Depression by creating jobs and to promote environmental conservation. Young men who enlisted in the ""Tree Army""; built roads, fire towers, bridges and canals, and planted trees for reforestation and erosion control. By 1942, the CCC had built 800 parks and planted 3 billion trees. The program was one of the most popular of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal programs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Organizations; Public Service Employment; Group portraits
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: P & R Photo Service, Grove Hill, Ala.
